stream_context.summary: Kaze fixes a memory-related crash, then discusses major engine refactors aimed at removing original Mario 64 actor code. The stream’s core design work is rethinking how Overworld Part 8 is gated so players aren’t overwhelmed, leading to a new comedic “sleepy Bob-omb guard” concept that launches Mario into a prerequisite side level. In parallel, Kaze explores a dark, dynamically-lit cave/maze side level concept (per-vertex lighting requiring hex-like tessellation) and runs into decomp-level plumbing issues when trying to add/define more courses, briefly breaking the save’s star count.
stream_context.significance_reason: Contains project-wide technical progress (nearly fully removing SM64 actor code), a key overworld progression/gating redesign for Part 8, and a concrete new side-level concept tied to caps plus dynamic lighting constraints; also reveals pain points in extending the decomp’s course/star infrastructure.

findings.summary: Kaze fixed a recurring crash related to the “safe block,” identifying it as an out-of-memory issue rather than a logic bug.

After weeks of refactoring, Kaze reports that almost all original Mario 64 actor code has been removed; remaining legacy actors are primarily Chain Chomp, Pokey, and Whirlpool, with plans to replace them as well.
findings.quote: Guys, you have no idea how much time I spent in the last few weeks refactoring stuff.

findings.summary: Kaze’s plan is to remove the original Whirlpool actor after Biobak finishes the Ice Cap rework, then implement a custom Whirlpool specific to RTYI.
Kaze calls out Pokey as “very buggy” and expects to remake the actor rather than patch it, reinforcing the broader strategy of replacing inherited SM64 behaviors instead of maintaining them.

Kaze re-evaluates the intended method for opening access to Overworld Part 8: the original concept involved discovering underwater tunnels and breaking something that triggers a change elsewhere in the overworld, but he now dislikes it because it would likely be found too early, feel overwhelming, and seem unintuitive (action far away causing a change here).

Kaze explicitly frames overworld gating as an anti-overwhelm measure: he wants players to unlock only one or two major areas/levels at a time, not three at once, to keep exploration readable and progression paced.
findings.quote: I don't want the player to get to every overworld part at once… one or two is the absolute most we can do, otherwise it's going to be overwhelming.

findings.summary: A new gating approach emerges: a simple, funny NPC barrier (a sleepy Bob-omb-like guard) that escalates into being launched into a prerequisite side level (via the guard’s “son”) before Part 8 becomes accessible.

Kaze explores tying this gate to cap progression: he proposes requiring a cap (he debates Cloud Cap vs Wing Cap, noting the Wing Cap is obtained in this overworld) to complete the prerequisite side level, making Part 8 access a mechanical milestone rather than a paywall or arbitrary star count.
findings.quote: I don't want to do any more pay barriers if I can avoid it. The pay barrier is the absolute last resort if you have no other idea.

findings.summary: For a planned dark side level with dynamic lighting, Kaze explains a hard art/tech constraint: per-vertex lighting will look wrong unless the environment is built with relatively even vertex spacing (“hex tessellated”-like topology), influencing the entire level’s geometry style.

The dark-level concept shifts toward a short, atmosphere-forward maze where the player follows a moving light (inspired by a “Dampé-like” follow-the-guide setup), potentially with failure pressure (e.g., poison gas) to prevent getting stuck and to keep the section brief.
findings.quote: The gameplay is just atmosphere and vibes.

findings.summary: Kaze describes his collaboration loop with Biobak: Kaze produces a rough “V1” concept and sends it; Biobak executes with significant creative freedom and typically shares work only when it’s nearly finished, asking viability questions when needed; Kaze says it’s rare he has to undo Biobak’s changes.

While preparing to add/import new side levels, Kaze discovers he has never added new side levels/courses in this codebase before and has to modify multiple decomp tables (level-to-course mappings, course defines/counts, EEPROM bytes). His attempt to clean up “hacky” decomp macros briefly corrupts the save’s star count (10 stars becomes 7), forcing a rollback and postponing the cleanup.
findings.quote: I'mma be honest, I need to figure out how to add more stars to this without fucking everything up.

findings.summary: When asked about Steam, Kaze says he might make a custom-IP version someday, implying he’s at least considering a non-ROMhack distribution path separate from Nintendo’s IP.
Kaze speculates Nintendo may follow his progress, joking that they could be watching streams; no concrete takedown or direct contact is mentioned in this stream.

biobak.summary: Biobak proposes/aligns with an “escape room with platforming puzzles” framing for the dark section and contributes to converging on a simple follow-the-guide-light concept (later framed as a Dampé-like ‘follow a Boo’ event).

Biobak’s feedback helps keep the solution simple and bounded in scope (a small section rather than an overcomplicated multi-mechanic level), which Kaze repeatedly emphasizes as necessary for pacing and feasibility.

key_stories.title: Removing nearly all original Mario 64 actor code
key_stories.summary: Kaze explains that he has spent weeks refactoring and stripping out SM64 actor behaviors to make RTYI functionally its own game rather than a mod that rides on inherited logic. Only a few legacy actors remain (Chain Chomp, Pokey, Whirlpool), and he outlines plans to remove or remake them.
key_stories.challenge: Inherited SM64 actor code is either unnecessary for RTYI’s design goals or too buggy/limiting to maintain long-term, and some components (e.g., Pokey) are unreliable.
key_stories.process: Kaze refactors the behavior/actor system file-by-file, removes unused actors, and schedules replacements (custom Whirlpool; Pokey remake). He coordinates timing with Biobak’s Ice Cap rework to avoid disrupting dependent content.
key_stories.outcome: RTYI is close to being ‘basically all custom code,’ with a clear remaining checklist of legacy actors to replace.
key_stories.key_quote: With that, all actor code in R64 is removed from the game… it’s basically all gone.

key_stories.title: Rethinking how Overworld Part 8 opens (anti-overwhelm gating)
key_stories.summary: Kaze revisits the planned unlock for Overworld Part 8 and rejects the earlier underwater-tunnel ‘break something far away’ trigger. He prioritizes readability and pacing so players don’t accidentally open too much content during initial exploration, then ideates toward a simple comedic ‘sleepy guard’ barrier that launches the player into a prerequisite side level.
key_stories.challenge: The original unlock path would likely be discovered too early, feel unintuitive (remote cause/effect), and risk overwhelming players by opening multiple areas/levels at once.
key_stories.process: Kaze evaluates barrier types (star-gate Womp, disguise gag, paywall), rejects pay barriers as a last resort, and develops a new gate that doubles as a side-level insertion point. He considers tying access to cap progression (debating which cap is obtained here).
key_stories.outcome: A concrete direction: a sleepy Bob-omb-style NPC triggers a side level (via ‘calling his son’ to launch Mario), and beating that side level becomes the justification for Part 8 access—keeping progression controlled while integrating planned side content.
key_stories.key_quote: I don't want the player to get to every overworld part at once… one or two is the absolute most we can do.

key_stories.title: Dynamic-lighting side level meets geometry constraints (hex-like tessellation)
key_stories.summary: To build a dark cave/maze side level, Kaze outlines an engine/art constraint: per-vertex lighting requires evenly distributed vertices, pushing the level’s environment toward hex-like tessellation rather than typical cubic architecture. He and chat converge on a short ‘follow the moving light’ maze (Dampé-like), with ideas for light sources ranging from Bob-ombs to a glowing companion.
key_stories.challenge: Dynamic lighting can look wrong or uneven if geometry has inconsistent vertex spacing; meanwhile, the level must remain simple and not frustrating in darkness.
key_stories.process: Kaze experiments with tessellation patterns, evaluates scale/claustrophobia, and debates light-source mechanics (glowing Boos, escort-like glowing baby Yoshi on Mario’s head, torches/Bob-ombs). He considers fail-safes to prevent getting stuck (guide light always at next node; fade-out/kick-out behavior).
key_stories.outcome: A feasible concept direction is chosen (small maze section guided by a moving light), but Kaze flags remaining unknowns: exact tessellation approach, light behavior, and anti-stuck logic.

key_stories.title: Extending the decomp’s course/star system breaks the save (star count drops)
key_stories.summary: While trying to add new courses/side levels, Kaze digs into decomp-defined tables and macros (course enums/counts, level-to-course mappings, EEPROM bytes). Attempted cleanup causes unexpected side effects: the save’s star count changes from 10 to 7, and he has to undo changes and defer the cleanup.
key_stories.challenge: The decomp’s infrastructure for courses/stages is ‘hacky’ and difficult to extend safely; Kaze needs more courses/stars/side levels without corrupting save data or breaking mappings.
key_stories.process: He locates multiple mapping tables (including a forgotten second table), modifies course count logic, searches for where EEPROM bytes are assigned, validates by checking star totals, then rolls back when counts change.
key_stories.outcome: He pauses the cleanup and decides to revisit later, acknowledging this as a prerequisite to importing the new side level cleanly.
key_stories.key_quote: I have 7 stars… Okay, wait, let me undo that.

open_questions.topic: Actor code purge: what’s left and why
open_questions.context: Kaze says nearly all SM64 actors are removed, with Chain Chomp, Pokey, and Whirlpool remaining (and some minor Mario/Goomba parts). He plans to remove Whirlpool after the Ice Cap rework and remake Pokey due to bugs.
questions: What specific problems did inherited SM64 actor code cause (bugs, performance, design constraints), and what was the tipping point for deciding to remove it wholesale?
Which parts of Mario and Goomba are still ‘legacy,’ and what would it take to call the codebase 100% custom?
Why is Whirlpool removal dependent on the Ice Cap rework—what is the dependency (level scripting, visuals, collision, behavior hooks)?
What were the worst refactor regressions during this purge, and how did you validate you didn’t break unrelated levels?

open_questions.topic: Overworld Part 8 gating: final design and pacing targets
open_questions.context: Kaze rejects the underwater tunnel ‘break something’ trigger due to overwhelm and unintuitive cause/effect. He leans toward a comedic sleepy Bob-omb guard who launches Mario into a prerequisite side level, potentially cap-gated.
questions: Where exactly is Part 8 in the intended progression (star count range / course order), and what player skills should it assume?
What is the final intended gate: beat-a-side-level, have-a-cap, star-count, or a combination—and why?
How will the game communicate the gate diegetically (NPC dialog, visual cues like a rock wall hiding the path) so it feels ‘earned’ rather than arbitrary?
How do you decide when it’s okay to open 2 levels at once versus 1—do you have a pacing rubric or playtest feedback driving that?

open_questions.topic: Dark ‘follow-the-light’ side level: mechanics, fail states, and accessibility
open_questions.context: Kaze develops a Dampé-like follow-a-glowing-entity maze in darkness with per-vertex dynamic lighting constraints. He considers poison gas, fade-out kick-outs, or guide behavior to avoid softlocks.
questions: What is the exact ‘loss condition’ for the dark maze (poison gas timer, getting lost, falling), and how do you prevent it from feeling unfair?
Will the guiding light be a Boo, a different entity, or a custom character—and why is that choice thematically tied to RTYI’s world?
How do you plan to handle exploration vs. guidance—do you want secrets in the darkness, and if so, how do you prevent players from getting trapped?
Will Mario himself emit light, and how will that interact with stealth/visibility and performance on N64 hardware?

open_questions.topic: Hex tessellation requirement: production impact on level art pipeline
open_questions.context: Kaze claims even vertex spacing is needed for good-looking per-vertex lighting, making certain architectural styles (cubic mineshaft) hard to light consistently.
questions: How often do engine constraints like vertex-lighting tessellation force you to redesign an environment concept? Any other major examples besides this dark cave?
Do artists (Biobak/Zeina) build geometry with these constraints in mind from the start, or do you retrofit tessellation after concepts are made?
What tooling (Blender scripts, exporters, in-engine checks) do you use to enforce or validate ‘even’ vertex spacing?
What’s the performance tradeoff between denser tessellation for smoother lighting versus triangle budget in these side levels?

open_questions.topic: Adding courses/side levels in the decomp: why it broke star count
open_questions.context: Kaze modifies decomp course tables/defines and observes star count changing from 10 to 7, implying he touched something linked to save data or course indexing (EEP bytes).
questions: What exactly caused the star count to drop—was it course enum reordering, EEPROM byte offsets, or a mapping table mismatch?
How do you plan to add new courses safely going forward (e.g., stable ID assignments, migration scripts for saves, hard versioning)?
What is your current ‘side level system’ architecture (course-less levels vs. course-numbered), and why is it ‘upper side level system’ still pending?
Do you have automated tests or a checklist to catch these regressions earlier than ‘load save and count stars’?
